abstract.p: Gurney flaps are small devices whose dimensions are usually percentage units of the airfoil chord. A Gurney flap can change the flow field in the region of the trailing edge by introducing two contra-rotating vortices behind the flap, therein altering Kutta’s condition and circulation. This helps avoiding flow separation and moves stall occurrence to higher angles of attack. Active rotor technologies would, for instance, enable a helicopter to operate at reduced rotor tip speed while preserving flight performance capabilities. This article shows some results carried out on different, original, and feasible solutions, aimed at realizing “smart” Gurney flaps for rotorcraft blades. In particular, piezo patches, piezo stacks, and electromagnet-based solutions were exploited finding that only the last two solutions are able to satisfy specs. The last one (electromagnets) performs better from the viewpoints of implementation, cost (one order of magnitude), weight (less than 100 g with respect to 150 g of piezo stack), and power consumption (5 W with respect to 50 W).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Liebeck (1978) first introduced the Gurney flap concept, when he provided wind tunnel results comparing the behavior of a naked airfoil versus an airfoil equipped with a 1.25% chord-long Gurney flap. It showed significant increased lift and decreased drag values. Liebeck (1978) also noted that increased flap length could lead to significant rises in drag while still leading to lift benefit. He then concluded that optimal Gurney flap length should be fixed at 1%c–2%c.

From a technological solution point of view, Yen et al. (2000) investigated a microtab-based load control system for wind turbine blade application. It was characterized by small tabs located close to the rotor blade trailing edge and deployed approximately normal to the skin. It effectively changed the local camber of the rotor blade and the local flow conditions and then modifying the whole blade aerodynamics. Microtabs showed relevant to be advantages such as low-power requirement, short actuation time, and simplicity, and above all, it required minimal changes in the original blade architecture and manufacture. Then, the same authors tested the load control capabilities of that system in a wind tunnel for a fixed wing (Yen et al., 2001). Tests demonstrated both the robustness and lift enhancement effects of the proposed device.

Chandrasekhara (2004) proposed an adaptive droop nose, aimed at controlling two-dimensional (2D) compressible dynamic stall and the associated adverse pitching moment. The results were satisfactory with reference to the target, but the price of that success was a 10% loss of aerodynamic lift. To recover the desired performance levels, a Gurney flap was attached to the trailing edge intradox lower skin, working like a microtab. The optimum flap height was determined as a function of the span (three-dimensional (3D)) all along the retreating blade region (incompressible flow) where the device was expected to produce its maximum effect. Airfoils were equipped with three separate Gurney flaps, 1%c–3%c high; again, the results confirmed that the best performance was attained at the smaller flap height.

In the initial technology review report, Paternoster et al. (2009) implemented different technologies to realize a practical Gurney flap, based on piezoelectric stack and patch devices. The respective performances were compared. In the following table, retrieved from Paternoster et al. (2009), required weight and power per span meter and for the whole blade (6.55 m) are presented:

Linear actuator solution was found 40% lighter than the stack actuator solution. However, these latter devices showed a better bandwidth (Yu et al., 1997), allowing the implementation of an additional active vibration reduction system in a range up to 4/rev.

In order to design a generic Gurney flap system properly, at least three parameters should be taken into account: aircraft type, reference flight conditions, and blade airfoil. Among the several solutions that can be found in the international scientific literature, a selection may be performed if bandwidth and weight characteristics are considered.

Inside the JTI-GRC1 “Innovative Rotor Blade” project, the active Gurney flap (AGF) concept was selected as a good trade-off between relatively low technological complexity and high effectiveness in improving blade performance. Therein, the authors investigated different solutions for realizing an AGF. In this article, the main conclusions of that activity are reported.

This article is structured following the study logic. At first, main requirements and characteristics are collected and discussed. Then, a selection of smart material–based devices is developed and investigated: in particular, electromagnets and piezoelectric stack are referred to.
Considered figures of merit are as follows:

list-item.p: Required mechanical energy, to actuate the flap against the most severe aerodynamic load condition (minimum);
Actuator bandwidth, to permit a full cycle within a single-blade revolution (largest);
Capability of sustaining expected centrifugal forces (maximum).

sec.p: The authors evaluate the performance of three different AGF mechanisms, referring to a basic architecture using a simple cantilever beam and smart material actuators as generators of the actuating force. Piezo patches, piezo stacks, and electromagnets are considered. The first one does not seem to have adequate authority to produce sufficient displacement at the reference frequencies. Instead, stack actuators are proved to achieve the prescribed levels of movement; however, power consumption and added weight penalties seem excessive for actual rotorcraft applications. Electromagnet actuators are the most promising devices: preliminary tests show the desired structural response is attained with limited electrical power consumption (<5 W) and extremely low-weight penalty (<100 g) on a clamped beam of 15 mm width, 195 mm long, and 0.5 mm thick. However, there is not any consideration to inertial loads on Gurney flap mechanism, associated with rotor blade flap, lag, and torsion motion, which will be presented in forthcoming study.

Reported results were achieved and elaborated at the Smart Structures and Vibroacoustics Laboratory of the Italian Aerospace Research Centre (CIRA), where the concepts were proposed and are currently being developed.

sec.title: Geometrical requirements
sec.p: Because stall phenomena arise in the region of thicker profiles (until 75% spanwise), only these profiles are referred to. In the current application, NACA 23012 is selected (Figure 1). This figure refers to the profile thickness of the rotor blade airfoil versus the position x/c along the chord, starting from the leading edge at the origin of the axes till the trailing edge.

caption.p: AGF: active Gurney flap; NACA: National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics.

sec.p: Following Van Dam et al. (2006), the best AGF position is at the trailing edge; performance deteriorates as it is moved upstream (toward the leading edge). Really, no significant performance loss is shown for locations up to 95%c, while appreciable effects maintain up to 90%c, as shown from Figure 1, at the 90%c, the available thickness for the Gurney flap height is about 20 mm.

Other authors (Kentfield, 1993; Maughmer et al., 2005; Myose et al., 1998) consolidated preliminary achievements of Liebeck (1978) and Yen et al. (2001), confirming the smallest one as the best device, selected among a variety ranging between 1.0%c and 2.5%c high. The herein reported study focuses on the development of new actuators allowing an AGF protrusion up to 2%c but not restrained to this value.

sec.title: Deployment law and dynamic requirements
sec.p: The law regulating the device height is fundamental to identify dynamic and general characteristics of the actuation system. Such a deployment law can have a shape as the one reported in Figure 2. This law shows three main intervals: on and off domain (AGF extended or retracted, completely) and transition domains (climb and descent, typically symmetric). The latter ones are the most critical, determining the dynamic response of the device. According to that, AGF shall pass from a fully retracted to a fully extended state position in about 10 ms, corresponding to about 10°–15° azimuth angle interval at the considered speed. A mean deployment velocity of about 1.5 m/s follows, corresponding to an about 150 m/s2 acceleration. The actuation frequency is fixed at 4 Hz (once per round).

sec.title: Deployment law synthesis
sec.p: In order to synthesize the signal, it is split into its main harmonics. In order to satisfy bandwidth requirements, the first 10 harmonics are used, with their own amplitudes and phases. Low-energy components are filtered. In this specific case, the seventh and the eighth addenda can be removed from the Fourier series due to their low energy content (see Figure 3). The final synthesized deployment law is shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Deployment law reconstruction using the highest among the first 10 components (seventh and eighth neglected).

sec.title: Technological solutions
sec.p: The technological solutions, investigated by the authors to develop an AGF system, are illustrated in this section. All of them are based on a simple, tip-flapped, cantilever beam. In Figure 5, a schematic of the concept design is drowned. The orientation of the beam with respect to the blade radius and chord can be deduced.

The beam elasticity works as an amplification device to produce the requested dynamic performance (basically, AGF deployment in terms of amplitude and time response). Other kinematic and sliding mechanisms are then avoided, simplifying the system behavior above all with respect to centrifugal forces, whose effects are, for the moment not taken into consideration, and will be a part of the next part of this research activity.

Three different technological solutions, described in the following, were exploited by means of simple analytical models (mainly one-dimensional (1D) and 2D) to highlight the main parameters affecting the performance of the device without performing accurate 3D finite element (FE) calculations.

sec.title: Piezoelectric ceramic patches
sec.p: A first approach is based on piezo patch actuators, bonded on both sides of the cantilever beam, as reported in Figure 6 (bending excitation). As an extreme option, the actuators could cover the whole 1D structural element. In more practical cases, a limited surface should however be considered. The resulting AGF should take into account some structural dynamics issues as, for instance, resonances that can give rise to phase and motion amplitude instabilities. These considerations address the design to static-like systems (magnitude and phase can be in fact thought to be constant in that frequency region).

Following these remarks, the first structural eigenfrequencies are set higher than the highest harmonic, used for the deployment law synthesis (hh = 35 Hz). sec.title: Piezoelectric stacks
sec.p: A second possibility involves piezoelectric stack actuators, able to generate very large forces but small deformations. Placing the actuator close to the clamp, large tip displacement may be assured (Figure 8).

Each stack is characterized by a curve that links the maximum actuation force (P), to the maximum achievable displacement (ystack): the characteristic of the actuator. The working point can then be obtained as the intersection between this curve and the elastic characteristic of the structure itself as reported in Figure 9. Maximization of the study leads to an optimal operating point of (ystack/2, P/2) (Prechtl and Hall, 1999).

Structural equations are used, referring to a cantilever beam under a concentrated load, to express the tip displacement (coincident with the AGF deployment) in this configuration as a function of the exciting force. Equation (1) is again used to fix the upper limit of the beam length. AGF displacement is expressed as a product of two terms, one depending on beam physic and geometric characteristics and another depending on actuator performances

sec.title: Electromagnets
sec.p: A further alternative concerns electromagnets. As a first step, numerical simulations are performed to evaluate the main characteristics of the generated attracting forces.

FEMM 4.2 open source code is used for these computations (www.femm.info/wiki/HomePage). An important characteristic is the electromagnetic holding force, Fh, defined as the force, necessary to detach a chunk of iron in a direction perpendicular to its surface. For a cylindrical electromagnet, this force depends on the following factors:

list-item.p: The magnetic gap: it is defined as the distance between the electromagnet and a generic piece of iron; Fh is maximum if the two surfaces are perfectly adherent and smooth (magnetic gap uniform and null).
Thickness of the iron piece to be attracted, S, strongly influencing the maximum attainable value of Fh; it is maximum if S is higher than the inner diameter of the electromagnet.

sec.title: Electromagnetic AGF—cyclic performance
sec.p: The last actuation mechanism seems to be the most promising, among those evaluated, in terms of whether weight, power consumption, or price. Response time can be further improved by optimizing geometrical and mechanical parameters of the system.

To check the system behavior under cyclic loads, an electronic board is manufactured to drive the electromagnet actuators at a desired frequency, in this case 4 Hz. Frequency and duty cycle can be adjusted by two external resistors (RA and RB) and one capacitor (C). The capacitor charges and discharges between 1/3 and 2/3 Vcc (in the experiment, Vcc = 12 V). sec.p: One-second time records (Figure 15) show other frequency components over the main carrier signal (a switch at about 4 Hz—the main rotor frequency). Difference between upper and lower lobes indicates the presence of some slight stiffness difference between the upper and lower system constraints (the lower one being more rigid).

Fast Fourier transformation (FFT) signal reported in Figure 16 indicates a clear peak at about 4 Hz, the excitation frequency. Other minor peaks do appear at the first beam bending mode (about 6 Hz), at the excitation frequency harmonics and other meshing frequencies due to nonlinearity in the system.

sec.title: Conclusions and future steps
sec.p: In this document, performance of three AGF devices is evaluated, whose common architecture is based on a simple cantilever beam. The different systems implement piezoelectric patches, piezoelectric stacks, and electromagnetic actuators, respectively.

Patch actuators, despite their very low weight (<10 g), do not result adequate to produce tip required displacements (3.5 mm for the epoxy beam). Stack actuators do achieve the desired behavior; however, it should be placed at only 0.5 mm of distance from the clamped edge; moreover, power consumption and added weight (50 W and 150 g) do seem excessive penalties for actual rotorcraft applications.

Electromagnet-based system demonstrates to be the most effective solution among the different herein tested. The specified displacement is achieved, yet in the early proposed configuration. A 28-ms time response is measured, associated with low electrical power consumption (about 5 W) and low-weight penalty (less than 100 g). As a next step, a full closed-loop control system will be designed and realized via digital signal processor (DSP).

Further experimental activities on a refined prototype will be aimed at optimizing the dynamic behavior of the device in terms of response time, absorbed power, and weight; operational forces, including centrifugal effects, will be considered.
